answers.author: Mary Van Milligen
answers.text:
The City of Woodbury passed a new special event policy just weeks ago. Similar to Olathe, Woodbury because a popular destination for charitable events, frontline staff needed specific direction on which events to assist with and which to charge. The city now only offers resources to four long standing community events and all other events pay for all staff time, etc. Woodbury based non-profits do not pay the $25 application fee. 
I have attached the new special event policy. We also created a special event guide, to assist any organization hosting an event with the planning and logistics.

answers.author: Sara Ott
answers.text:
This happens regularly in our community as well.  The City charges an application fee of $125 to review the request and will also charge for all city services, including traffic control measures,  for around $100/worker/hour.  We do not allow volunteers to staff road closures for safety reasons.  This has worked well in deterring the number of these events.   This is the link to our application form    http://dublinohiousa.gov/events/event-guidebook-event-application/ 
Additionally, non-profits are eligble to apply for a grant for city services for their events.   Grant receipents must meet specific guidelines to be eligible to receive the grant, typically around increasing overnight stays in the community.    
http://dublinohiousa.gov/taxation/hotelmotel-tax-grant/ 
Lastly, we enourage the use of the bike path system to mimize road closures.  To do this the starting point of the run is in a park or road so there is a large area for the start of the event, registration, etc.   Once pace groups are set, it seems to work out fine.    
Good luck!

answers.author: Maya Williams
answers.text:
We have a Special Event Ordinance that lays out the detials for all special events.  In terms of the fees, the opportunity cost for producing large events is cost prohibitive for event organizers, however...we have flat rate for staff time the day of the event.  As in the case of a street closure, we charge applicants for Police and Maintenance time.  Many cities in the area charge for full cost recovery, we do not.
Police Officers - $84.81 per hour
Fire Employees - $59.83 per hour
Maintenance Employees - $50.07 per hour
Other Police Department Employees - $46.28 per hour
Also, We have a permit structure that charges a permit fee from $50 to $200.  Please see:  http://www.fremont.gov/index.aspx?NID=622
Last, "Special Event Safety Seminars" offers and amazing training on all of this.  A lot of jurisdictions use this firm for training. www.SpecialEventSafety.com

answers.author: Jerene Watson
answers.text:
Our Special Events coordinator, Glorice Pavey, provided us this specific response - sorry for the delay, but I thought it was already posted back to you:
We permit street closures for charity 5K and have a separate fee structure for nonprofits.  We require that a nonprofit has been recognized as tax exempt by the Internal Revenue Service at least six months prior to the event date.  A copy of the tax exemption letter is required.
Fees Charged: 
•   $41.75 Application fee (fee is the same for non-profit or commercial events)
o   Our application fee is tiered, dependent upon the complexity of the event.  Street closures and events that have alcohol will pay the most because they are the most complex types of permit applications.
•   $10 per street block, (7 hours or less) for “hard” street closures (discounted for nonprofits)
o   Anything over 7 hours is charged $20 per block
•   $25 for staging (fee is the same for non-profit and commercial events)-this is often used for parades, who may take up over 15 City blocks to stage their floats.  In regards to 5Ks and 10Ks, this fee is applied to the start/finish line.
•   $21 Overnight closure per block for “hard” street closures (discounted for nonprofits)
•   $350 refundable deposit
The difference between a hard closure and a soft closure is dependent on if vehicle traffic will be prohibited from entering the event area and the street is cordoned off with barricades (hard closure) or if vehicle traffic is temporarily held by a police officer, so that racers may pass through the intersection safely (soft closure).  Soft closures do not incur any cost to the event producer.
We ask that event producers pay for officer time.  Oftentimes, the police department is able to use grants to offset this cost and many nonprofits do not see a fee associated with pd time.  This rarely occurs with commercial events.  The cost incurred by other departments, when processing the application is absorbed in our day-to-day operations and is covered by the minimal “application fee”, listed above.  
Fees for portable toilets and trash/recycling are the responsibility of the event producer.  A certificate of insurance, naming the City of Flagstaff as additional insured for one million in general, alcohol and/or auto liability is required and the fees incurred with getting the certificate is the responsibility of the event producer.
As for barricades, we adhere to the Uniform Manual on Traffic Control Devices, a federally recognized standard for street closures.  It is the responsibility of the event producer to submit a “traffic control plan” to be approved by our traffic engineer.  The cost of creating this document and implementing the barricades is the responsibility of the event producer.  Per the Uniform Manual on Traffic Control Devices, the traffic control plan and all barricades must be implemented by a certified barricade company.  
As for scheduling events, we are limited as to the number of places to hold races and other street closures.  We cannot permit events to occur on streets governed by other agencies.  Many of our City streets are bisected by State streets or railroad crossings.  Our historic downtown is a popular venue for events, however many of the businesses do not feel that the events benefit their sales.  Some would argue that the events take away on-street parking and they see a decline in sales.  Because of this, our City Council has asked to approve street closures in the downtown area.  This allows businesses and residents the opportunity to voice support or concern regarding the street closure.   
As for limiting the number of events that can occur on a given day, we do not limit events.  We keep track of events in a recreation reservation system and do not overbook parks, facilities or streets.  It is not uncommon to have up to 10 events on a summer day around the Flagstaff area.  This is not a strain on our police department, as many of these events are simple craft shows, concerts, etc.
To receive an electronic transmission of our Special Events packet, application and fee schedule, contact Glorice Pavey, 928-213-2312, gpavey@flagstaffaz.gov

author: Susan Sherman
text: The city of Olathe, KS, has become a popular destination for charitable 5Ks and while we want to accomodate these special events for our community, the cost and time, both in people and resources is getting to be difficult.   I am looking for some best practices on special event permitting and regulation on how many events  can be scheduled on any one day.  We currently only charge $15 per permit and no charge for all the traffic, police, fire etc.   Our Council has not been willing to charge due to the charitible nature of the events.   Thoughts, insights, and best practices would be much appreciated.
title: Special Events Management and Permits
